message_1: A right triangle has a hypotenuse of length 10cm and one of its angles measures 30 degrees. What are the lengths of the other two sides (in cm)?
message_2:
Let's call the side opposite the 30-degree angle "a" and the side adjacent to the 30-degree angle "b". We can use the sine and cosine functions to find the lengths of these sides.

sin(30) = a / 10
cos(30) = b / 10

sin(30) = 1/2, so:

1/2 = a / 10
a = 10 * 1/2
a = 5 cm

cos(30) = √3/2, so:

√3/2 = b / 10
b = 10 * √3/2
b = 5√3 cm

So, the lengths of the other two sides are 5 cm and 5√3 cm.
